name: Cai Lun
summary: Cai Lun was a Chinese court official credited with inventing the modern process of papermaking in 105 AD. He refined earlier paper production methods by using tree bark, hemp, rags, and fishnets to create a lightweight, affordable writing material. His invention transformed communication, education, and civilization worldwide.
timeline: Born in Guiyang, Han Dynasty China
Presented improved papermaking process to Emperor He
Elevated to nobility for his invention

name: Bi Sheng
summary: Bi Sheng was a Chinese artisan who invented movable type printing around 1040 during the Song Dynasty, approximately 400 years before Gutenberg. He created individual character types from baked clay that could be arranged, used for printing, and then rearranged. His invention, documented by Shen Kuo, was a revolutionary advance in printing technology.
timeline: Invented movable type printing using baked clay

name: Shen Kuo
summary: Shen Kuo was a brilliant Song Dynasty polymath who made discoveries in astronomy, mathematics, geology, optics, and cartography. His encyclopedic work Dream Pool Essays documented magnetic compass navigation, movable type printing, and geological observations centuries ahead of Western science. He described the concept of true north and understood geological processes of erosion and sedimentation.
timeline: Appointed head of Bureau of Astronomy

name: Zhang Heng
summary: Zhang Heng was a Han Dynasty polymath who invented the world's first seismoscope in 132 AD, capable of detecting distant earthquakes. He also constructed an armillary sphere, calculated pi as 3.1466, and proposed that the Moon reflected sunlight rather than producing its own. He was one of the greatest scientists of ancient China.

name: Su Song
summary: Su Song was a Song Dynasty astronomer and mechanical engineer who built the Cosmic Engine in 1088, a sophisticated astronomical clock tower that was the world's first known endless power-transmitting chain drive mechanism. Standing 12 meters tall, it combined a water-driven clock, armillary sphere, and celestial globe.
timeline: Completed the Cosmic Engine (astronomical clock tower)
Published Xin Yi Xiang Fa Yao (astronomical atlas)

name: Zu Chongzhi
summary: Zu Chongzhi was a Chinese mathematician and astronomer who calculated pi to seven decimal places (3.1415926 to 3.1415927), a record that stood for nearly a thousand years. He also developed the Daming calendar, the most accurate calendar of his time, and made significant contributions to mathematics including methods for calculating sphere volumes.
timeline: Born in Jiankang (Nanjing), Liu Song Dynasty
Developed method for sphere volume calculation
Calendar reforms adopted by Qi Dynasty

name: Li Shizhen
summary: Li Shizhen was a Ming Dynasty physician who compiled the Bencao Gangmu (Compendium of Materia Medica), the most comprehensive traditional Chinese medicine text. Over 27 years, he documented 1,892 drugs, 11,096 prescriptions, and included detailed botanical illustrations. His work is considered one of the greatest scientific achievements of pre-modern China.
timeline: Born in Qizhou, Hubei, Ming Dynasty

name: Qian Xuesen
summary: Qian Xuesen was the father of China's space and missile programs. After a distinguished career at Caltech and JPL, he was deported from the US during the McCarthy era. He returned to China where he founded the Chinese space program, overseeing the development of China's first ballistic missiles, satellites, and the Silkworm missile.
timeline: Went to MIT for graduate study
Joined Caltech under Theodore von Kármán
Oversaw launch of Dong Fang Hong 1 satellite

name: Tu Youyou
summary: Tu Youyou is a Chinese pharmaceutical chemist who discovered artemisinin, the most effective treatment for malaria. She won the 2015 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, becoming the first Chinese Nobel laureate in natural sciences. She extracted artemisinin from sweet wormwood using ancient Chinese herbal medicine texts as her guide.
timeline: Graduated from Peking University Pharmacy School
Appointed head of Project 523 malaria research
Artemisinin approved for clinical use in China
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Yuan Longping
summary: Yuan Longping was a Chinese agronomist known as the 'Father of Hybrid Rice.' He developed the first successful hybrid rice varieties in the 1970s, increasing yields by 20% and feeding hundreds of millions of additional people. His work is considered one of the greatest agricultural achievements of the 20th century. He continued improving rice yields throughout his life.
timeline: Hybrid rice adopted nationwide in China

name: Deng Jiaxian
summary: Deng Jiaxian was a Chinese nuclear physicist who led the development of China's first atomic bomb and hydrogen bomb. Working in complete secrecy for decades, he designed both weapons in remarkably short timeframes. He is revered as one of China's 'Two Bombs, One Satellite' heroes. He died from radiation exposure sustained during his weapons work.
timeline: Appointed chief designer of China's atomic bomb
China's first atomic bomb test successful

name: Qian Sanqiang
summary: Qian Sanqiang was a Chinese nuclear physicist who co-discovered the phenomenon of nuclear ternary fission. He studied under Irène and Frédéric Joliot-Curie in Paris and became one of the founders of China's nuclear weapons program. He served as director of the Institute of Atomic Energy and was known as the 'father of Chinese nuclear science.'
timeline: Went to Paris to study under Joliot-Curie
Led development of China's first nuclear reactor
Contributed to first Chinese atomic bomb test

name: Zhu Xi
summary: Zhu Xi was a Song Dynasty Neo-Confucian philosopher whose scientific observations included early concepts of geological change, fossils, and natural philosophy. He observed that marine fossils found on mountaintops proved the land had once been undersea, centuries before Western geologists made similar observations. His systematic approach influenced East Asian intellectual tradition.
timeline: Observed fossils on mountaintops, deduced geological change
Compiled and commented on the Four Books

name: Huang Daopo
summary: Huang Daopo was a Yuan Dynasty textile innovator who revolutionized cotton weaving technology in China. She learned advanced cotton processing techniques from the Li people of Hainan Island and introduced improved spinning wheels and looms to the Yangtze River Delta. Her innovations transformed the Chinese cotton industry and made Shanghai a textile center.
timeline: Learned cotton processing from Li people
Returned to mainland with improved techniques
Revolutionized cotton industry in Jiangnan region

name: Wang Zhen
summary: Wang Zhen was a Yuan Dynasty official and inventor who created wooden movable type and a revolving typecase system for efficient printing. He also authored the Nongshu (Book of Agriculture), a comprehensive agricultural encyclopedia documenting farming techniques, irrigation, and tools. His revolving typecase was an early form of print automation.

name: Guo Shoujing
summary: Guo Shoujing was a Yuan Dynasty astronomer and engineer who created the Shoushi calendar, the most accurate calendar in the world at that time. He calculated the length of the year to within 26 seconds of the modern value. He also designed water management systems and built 27 astronomical instruments including an advanced gnomon for measuring solar altitude.

name: Song Yingxing
summary: Song Yingxing was a Ming Dynasty scientist who authored the Tiangong Kaiwu (The Exploitation of the Works of Nature), an encyclopedia of science and technology. Published in 1637, it documented manufacturing processes including mining, ceramics, papermaking, metallurgy, and agriculture with detailed illustrations. It is considered China's most important pre-modern technology text.
timeline: Failed metropolitan examination, turned to scientific writing

name: Chen Jingrun
summary: Chen Jingrun was a Chinese mathematician who made groundbreaking progress on Goldbach's conjecture, proving that every sufficiently large even number can be expressed as the sum of a prime and a product of at most two primes (Chen's theorem, 1966). His work was considered the closest approach to proving Goldbach's conjecture and made him a national hero in China.
timeline: Proved Chen's theorem on Goldbach's conjecture
Published detailed proof of Chen's theorem
Became national hero after profile in People's Literature

name: Hua Luogeng
summary: Hua Luogeng (Hua Loo-Keng) was one of the greatest Chinese mathematicians of the 20th century, known for his contributions to number theory, algebra, and applied mathematics. Despite being self-taught due to poverty, he became a professor at Tsinghua University and spent years at Cambridge and Princeton. He later applied mathematics to optimize Chinese industrial production.
timeline: Invited to Cambridge University by G.H. Hardy
Returned to China, professor at Kunming
Visited Princeton Institute for Advanced Study
Applied optimization mathematics to Chinese industry
Died in Tokyo during lecture tour

name: Wu Wenjun
summary: Wu Wenjun was a Chinese mathematician who made pioneering contributions to algebraic topology and mechanical theorem proving. His Wu classes in topology and Wu's method for automated geometric theorem proving were groundbreaking. He received the inaugural State Preeminent Science and Technology Award of China in 2000.
timeline: Studied under Charles Ehresmann in Strasbourg
Developed Wu's method for automated theorem proving
Received State Preeminent Science and Technology Award

name: Li Siguang
summary: Li Siguang was a pioneering Chinese geologist who developed the theory of geomechanics and used it to predict the location of oil deposits in China. When foreign experts claimed China was oil-poor, his geological theories led to the discovery of the Daqing oil field and other major petroleum reserves, transforming China's energy landscape.
timeline: Earned doctorate from University of Birmingham
Returned to China, pioneered geological surveys
Predicted Daqing oil field using geomechanics
Daqing production made China oil self-sufficient

name: Zhu Kezhen
summary: Zhu Kezhen was the father of modern Chinese meteorology and geography. He established China's meteorological observation network and published a landmark study of climate change in China over 5,000 years using historical records. He served as president of Zhejiang University for 13 years, transforming it into a leading institution.
timeline: Became vice president of Chinese Academy of Sciences
Published study of 5,000 years of Chinese climate change

name: Yang Zhenning
summary: Yang Zhenning (Chen-Ning Yang) is a Chinese-American physicist who shared the 1957 Nobel Prize in Physics with Tsung-Dao Lee for their prediction of parity violation in weak interactions. He also developed the Yang-Mills theory, which became the foundation of the Standard Model of particle physics. He later returned to live in China.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Chicago
Predicted parity violation with T.D. Lee

name: Li Tsung-Dao
summary: Li Tsung-Dao (Tsung-Dao Lee) was a Chinese-American physicist who shared the 1957 Nobel Prize in Physics with Yang Zhenning for proposing that parity is not conserved in weak nuclear interactions. At age 30, he was one of the youngest Nobel laureates. He also made important contributions to statistical mechanics and field theory.
timeline: Went to University of Chicago for graduate study
Became youngest full professor at Columbia University
Proposed parity violation with C.N. Yang
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physics at age 30

name: Mao Yisheng
summary: Mao Yisheng was a pioneering Chinese structural engineer who designed and built the Qiantang River Bridge in 1937, the first modern bridge designed and built by Chinese engineers. He was forced to destroy his own bridge to slow the Japanese advance during WWII, then rebuilt it after the war. He is considered the father of Chinese bridge engineering.
timeline: Earned PhD from Carnegie Institute of Technology
Destroyed bridge to slow Japanese invasion

name: Wu Youxing
summary: Wu Youxing was a Ming Dynasty physician who proposed that epidemic diseases are caused by invisible pathogenic particles transmitted through the air, anticipating germ theory by over 200 years. His 1642 treatise Wen Yi Lun (Treatise on Pestilence) was one of the earliest works to suggest that different diseases have different specific causes.
timeline: Published Wen Yi Lun (Treatise on Pestilence)

name: Joseph Needham
summary: Joseph Needham was a British biochemist and historian who compiled the monumental Science and Civilisation in China, documenting China's vast scientific and technological contributions to world history. His work revealed that many inventions attributed to the West were actually first developed in China. His magnum opus spans 27 volumes and remains the definitive reference.
timeline: Went to China as British scientific liaison
Published first volume of Science and Civilisation in China

name: Wang Xuan
summary: Wang Xuan was a Chinese computer scientist who invented the Chinese electronic publishing system, revolutionizing Chinese-language printing and publishing. His laser typesetting system solved the enormous technical challenge of digitizing thousands of Chinese characters and was adopted by over 99% of Chinese newspapers. He is considered the 'Gutenberg of China.'
timeline: Began developing Chinese electronic publishing system
Created laser phototypesetting for Chinese characters
System adopted by major Chinese newspapers
Received State Preeminent Science and Technology Award

name: Peng Huanwu
summary: Peng Huanwu was a Chinese theoretical physicist who was one of the key scientists in China's nuclear weapons program. He studied under Max Born in Edinburgh and made contributions to quantum mechanics, nuclear physics, and statistical mechanics. He provided crucial theoretical calculations for China's first atomic and hydrogen bombs.
timeline: Studied under Max Born in Edinburgh
Provided theory for China's first atomic bomb

name: Wu Jianxiong
summary: Wu Jianxiong (Chien-Shiung Wu) was a Chinese-American experimental physicist who conducted the Wu experiment in 1957, which proved that parity is not conserved in weak interactions. Known as the 'First Lady of Physics,' she was the first woman to receive an honorary doctorate from Princeton. Despite her Nobel-caliber work, she was controversially not included in the Nobel Prize.
timeline: Designed experiment to test parity violation
Elected to National Academy of Sciences
Became first female president of American Physical Society

name: Tao Xingzhi
summary: Tao Xingzhi was a Chinese educator and reformer who pioneered mass education and science literacy in China. Influenced by John Dewey at Columbia University, he developed the concept of 'life education' integrating learning with practical experience. He founded numerous schools for the poor and advocated for scientific thinking in Chinese education.
timeline: Studied under John Dewey at Columbia University
Founded Yucai School for war refugees' children

name: Hou Debang
summary: Hou Debang was a Chinese chemical engineer who developed the Hou process for producing soda ash, an improvement over the Solvay process. He wrote the first comprehensive textbook on soda ash manufacturing and helped establish China's modern chemical industry. His process was more efficient and produced ammonium chloride fertilizer as a byproduct.
timeline: Established Yongli Soda Plant in China
Developed Hou process for soda ash production
Served as minister of chemical industry

name: Zhan Tianyou
summary: Zhan Tianyou was the father of Chinese railroad engineering, who designed and built the Beijing-Zhangjiakou Railway in 1909, the first major railroad built without foreign assistance. He solved the problem of crossing steep mountain passes using an ingenious zigzag switchback design. His achievement was a landmark of Chinese engineering independence.
timeline: Sent to study in the United States as a child
Began railroad engineering work in China
Appointed chief engineer of Beijing-Zhangjiakou Railway

name: Lin Lanying
summary: Lin Lanying was a Chinese materials scientist known as the 'mother of Chinese semiconductors.' She grew China's first silicon and gallium arsenide single crystals, which were essential for China's semiconductor, laser, and space technology development. She overcame significant obstacles as a woman in science during a turbulent period of Chinese history.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Pennsylvania
Grew China's first silicon single crystal
Grew China's first gallium arsenide crystal

name: Cheng Dawei
summary: Cheng Dawei was a Ming Dynasty mathematician who wrote the Suanfa Tongzong (General Source of Computational Methods) in 1592, one of the most influential Chinese mathematics texts. It systematized abacus calculation methods and remained the standard mathematics reference for over 300 years. The book spread to Korea, Japan, and Southeast Asia.
timeline: Began studying mathematics and commercial arithmetic
Book widely adopted across East Asia

name: Zhu Guangya
summary: Zhu Guangya was a Chinese nuclear physicist who was a key leader in China's nuclear weapons development program. He studied at the University of Michigan and returned to China in 1950. He served as chief scientist and organized the technical teams that successfully developed China's atomic and hydrogen bombs.
timeline: Awarded 'Two Bombs, One Satellite' meritorious medal

name: Ye Duzheng
summary: Ye Duzheng was a Chinese meteorologist who discovered the role of the Tibetan Plateau as a heat source driving the Asian monsoon. His work on atmospheric circulation over the Tibetan Plateau was fundamental to understanding Asian weather patterns. He co-authored pioneering studies on jet streams and atmospheric energy cycles.
timeline: Studied at University of Chicago under Carl-Gustaf Rossby
Published theory of Tibetan Plateau as atmospheric heat source
Elected to Chinese Academy of Sciences

name: Lu Jiaxi
summary: Lu Jiaxi was a Chinese structural chemist who made significant contributions to the chemistry of metal clusters and polyoxometalates. He served as president of the Chinese Academy of Sciences and was a leader in Chinese scientific development. His work on the structure and bonding of metal cluster compounds was internationally recognized.
timeline: Earned PhD from University College London
Established chemistry research at Xiamen University
Became president of Chinese Academy of Sciences

name: Zhao Jiuzhang
summary: Zhao Jiuzhang was a Chinese meteorologist and geophysicist who is considered the father of China's satellite program. He led the development of China's first artificial satellite, Dong Fang Hong 1. He also made important contributions to meteorology and atmospheric physics. He died during the Cultural Revolution.

name: Xu Guangqi
summary: Xu Guangqi was a Ming Dynasty scientist and scholar who collaborated with Matteo Ricci to translate Euclid's Elements into Chinese. He also wrote the Agricultural Administration, a comprehensive treatise on Chinese farming techniques. He was one of the first Chinese scholars to systematically integrate Western and Chinese scientific knowledge.
timeline: Co-translated first six books of Euclid's Elements

name: Mo Di
summary: Mo Di (Mozi) was an ancient Chinese philosopher, engineer, and scientist who founded the Mohist school. His followers developed formal logic, optics, mechanics, and geometry. The Mohist Canon contains descriptions of the camera obscura, principles of mechanics, and logical reasoning that paralleled Greek developments. He also designed defensive military siege equipment.
timeline: Mohist Canon began documenting scientific observations

name: Sun Simiao
summary: Sun Simiao was a Tang Dynasty physician known as China's 'King of Medicine.' He wrote the Beiji Qianjin Yaofang (Essential Prescriptions Worth a Thousand Gold), one of the earliest Chinese medical encyclopedias. He advocated treating all patients equally regardless of social status and documented the use of sulfur and saltpeter, foreshadowing gunpowder.

name: Ge Hong
summary: Ge Hong was an Eastern Jin Dynasty alchemist and physician whose Baopuzi documented early chemical experiments, medicinal treatments, and alchemical processes. He described the use of artemisinin-containing herbs for malaria treatment, which inspired Tu Youyou's Nobel Prize-winning discovery 1,700 years later. He also documented early smallpox treatment methods.
timeline: Published Baopuzi (The Master Who Embraces Simplicity)
Documented herbal remedies including artemisinin herbs

name: Mei Wending
summary: Mei Wending was a Qing Dynasty mathematician and astronomer who worked to integrate Western mathematical methods with traditional Chinese mathematics. He wrote over 80 works on mathematics and astronomy, demonstrating that Western mathematics had Chinese historical parallels. He helped preserve Chinese mathematical heritage during a period of Western scientific dominance.
timeline: Published works comparing Chinese and Western mathematics

name: Pei Wenzhong
summary: Pei Wenzhong was a Chinese paleontologist who discovered the first complete skull of Homo erectus pekinensis (Peking Man) at Zhoukoudian in 1929. This discovery was one of the most important finds in paleoanthropology, providing crucial evidence of human evolution. He became the father of Chinese paleontology and led archaeological research for decades.
timeline: Found evidence of fire use by Peking Man
Earned PhD from University of Paris
Peking Man fossils lost during WWII

name: Wu Zhongheng
summary: Wu Zhongheng was a Chinese chemical engineer who contributed to the development of China's synthetic materials and polymer industry. His research on petrochemical processing helped China achieve self-sufficiency in essential chemical products during the period of industrialization.
timeline: Developed synthetic materials for Chinese industry

name: Tong Dizhou
summary: Tong Dizhou was a Chinese biologist who was the first person to clone a fish (a carp) in 1963 by nuclear transfer, decades before Dolly the sheep. He overcame extreme poverty to become one of China's greatest biologists and made pioneering contributions to embryology and developmental biology. He served as vice president of the Chinese Academy of Sciences.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Brussels
Successfully cloned a carp by nuclear transfer
Became vice president of Chinese Academy of Sciences

name: Wang Yinglai
summary: Wang Yinglai was a Chinese biochemist who led the team that achieved the first total synthesis of crystalline bovine insulin in 1965, making China the first country to synthesize a protein. This landmark achievement in biochemistry demonstrated that proteins could be artificially created. He was a founder of modern Chinese biochemistry.
timeline: Achieved first total synthesis of bovine insulin

name: Zhang Yuzhe
summary: Zhang Yuzhe was a Chinese astronomer who discovered and named several asteroids, including 1125 China and 1802 Zhang. He was the first Chinese astronomer to discover an asteroid and the first to compute a comet's orbit. He served as director of the Purple Mountain Observatory and helped establish modern Chinese astronomy.
timeline: Earned PhD in astronomy from UC Berkeley
Became director of Purple Mountain Observatory
